questions.question_text: Standard Fiscal Years are for companies that break down their fiscal years,quarters and weeks in to fiscal periods.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Custom Fiscal Years
Some companies break down their fiscal years, quarters, and weeks into custom fiscal periods based on their financial planning requirements. Salesforce allows you to flexibly define these periods using custom fiscal years. For example, you can create a 13-week quarter represented by three periods of four, four, and five weeks, rather than calendar months.

Standard Fiscal Years in Salesforce are designed to cater to companies that divide their fiscal years into smaller periods such as quarters and weeks. By using Standard Fiscal Years, companies can align their financial reporting and planning processes with their specific fiscal periods.

With Standard Fiscal Years, you can define the start and end dates for each fiscal period, determine the number of periods within a fiscal year, and establish the organization's default fiscal year. This enables companies to accurately track and analyze financial data based on their unique fiscal timeframes.

questions.question_text: What statement is true regarding a custom field formula?

choices.A: Not reference standard, custom, or other objects
choices.C: 4000 character is the limit on the compiled size of the formula

discussion.content:
There is no relation between formula fields and characters. This can be an outdated question.

https://help.salesforce.com/s/articleView?id=sf.formula_field_limits.htm&type=5
"Save size limit — Formula fields can’t exceed 4,000 bytes when saved. If you use multi-byte characters in your formula, the save size is different from the number of characters
Compile size limit —Formula fields can’t exceed 15,000 bytes when compiled. The compile size is the size of the formula (in bytes) including all of the fields, values, and formulas it references. There’s no direct correlation between the compile size and the character limit. Some functions, such as TEXT, DATEVALUE, DATETIMEVALUE, and DATE significantly increase the compile size."

According to https://help.salesforce.com/articleView?id=sf.customize_ui_settings.htm&type=5
Formulas: maximum length 3,900 characters
Formulas: maximum size when compiled 5,000 bytes
Formulas: maximum size when saved 4,000 bytes

questions.question_text: In order to create a many-to-many relationship between two objects, a junction object must be created. This junction object will have a Master-Detail relationship to both objects.

discussion.content: A custom object with two master-detail relationships. Using a custom junction object, you can model a “many-to-many” relationship between two objects. For example, you create a custom object called “Bug” that relates to the standard case object such that a bug could be related to multiple cases and a case could also be related to multiple bugs.

questions.question_text: Active Currencies live in Company Profile, user record (Personal Setup) and in Opportunity (Record).

discussion.content: Currency appears on Users and Opportunities only if "Activate Multiple Currencies" is enabled under Company Information. The question is unclear under what circumstances we should look for a Currency field for these objects.

Selected Answer: B
Opp and user records do not have active currency fields.

questions.question_text: Users can be restricted to view a particular field in views, searches and reports by hiding the field at

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Users can be restricted from viewing a particular field in views, searches, and reports by using Field-Level Security (FLS) in Salesforce. FLS allows administrators to control the visibility and accessibility of fields at the user level.
